title: New Commission job titles ‘bizarre’: EU Parliament president
text:
'There has been a bit of lightness and haste which is indicated in names that were slightly original and bizarre,' European Parliament President David Sassoli said | John Thys/AFP via Getty Images New Commission job titles ‘bizarre’: EU Parliament president David Sassoli said Ursula von der Leyen would explain her decisions at a meeting next week.

David Sassoli, the president of the European Parliament, described the new Commission's portfolio names as "slightly original and bizarre" and said Ursula von der Leyen would clarify them at a meeting next week.

Incoming Commission President von der Leyen on Tuesday presented the names and portfolios of her new Commission, which includes several less-than-straightforward job titles such as vice presidents for "An Economy That Works for People" and "Protecting the European Way of Life."

Speaking to reporters at a press conference on Thursday, Sassoli said: “I imagine that given the possible rush to give names to these portfolios, there has been a bit of lightness and haste which is indicated in names that were slightly original and bizarre."

He added that von der Leyen had agreed to explain her decisions at a Conference of Presidents next week.

The portfolio name of Greece's Margaritis Schinas — "Protecting the European Way of Life" — sparked controversy shortly after von der Leyen unveiled her team.

MEPs are pressuring her to change the job title of Schinas, whose responsibilities include migration, saying the name was offensive and implied migrants and refugees posed a threat to the European way of life. Outgoing Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker also criticized the name on Thursday.

Sassoli didn't criticise the name of Schinas' portfolio openly. But he said he had noticed that “fundamental” portfolio names like “immigration,” “culture” and “research” were missing, adding: “I think that these words are very important."

“It’s not enough to say innovation and youth to talk about culture and research. And we at the Parliament, we know this well because we know these words and what they mean,” Sassoli said.

He was likely referring to the portfolio of Mariya Gabriel, the commissioner-designate for "innovation and youth," whose responsibilities also include research and innovation. Previous commissioners with this portfolio have had the word "research" in their titles.

Commenting briefly on Brexit, Sassoli said the Parliament was open to an extension of Article 50 but “only if justified.”
description: David Sassoli said Ursula von der Leyen would explain her decisions at a meeting next week.
